deleteDataConfirm.title: Delete all data
deleteDataConfirm.message: All your data will be permanently deleted: period tracking, symptoms, health logs, app settings, theme preferences, notification settings, and app lock configuration. This action cannot be undone.
deleteDataConfirm.successMessage: All your data has been deleted. The app will now restart.
deleteDataConfirm.errorMessage: Failed to delete data. Please try again.

appLockSettings.unlockDescription: Use your device's biometric authentication (e.g. fingerprint or face ID) to unlock
appLockSettings.noDeviceSecurityDescription: You need to setup your device's biometric authentication first to enable this feature.

error.title: Error
error.message: Failed to update app lock settings. Unable to complete security update. Please try again.
error.rewrapFailed: The security setting could not be applied. Your data is still safe with the old settings.

reminderSettings.title: Reminders
reminderSettings.description: Get notified before your next period
reminderSettings.beforePeriod: Remind me 3 days before my next period is likely to start.
reminderSettings.dayOfPeriod: Remind me the day of my period start.
reminderSettings.latePeriod: Remind me if my period is late.

permissionDialog.title: Enable Notifications
permissionDialog.message: To receive period reminders, please enable notifications for app in your device settings.

whatIs.description: Cicla is a privacy-first period tracking app designed to help you understand and manage your menstrual cycle.

features.title: Features
features.predictions: Ovulation day and fertile window predictions

privacyFirst.title: Privacy First
privacyFirst.description: Cicla is designed with a privacy-first approach:
privacyFirst.local: All data is stored locally and encrypted
privacyFirst.noTransmission: No data transmission to external servers

openSource.title: Open Source
openSource.warranty: Cicla is distributed in the hope that it will be useful, but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY

developer.title: About the Developer
developer.description: Cicla is by Ghazali, it is a Flutter port of Bluma originally made by Maribel Ferreira.

technical.title: Technical Details
technical.description: Cicla is built using Flutter to ensure reliability and performance:
technical.platform: Platform: Android not tested for IOS

footer.prefix: For support or feedback, please contact at:

introduction.description: This Privacy Policy sets out how the app uses and protects your personal data that you generate and store within the app.

dataUse.title: 1. Data Use
dataUse.descriptionPrefix: Cicla respects your privacy. There is no collection of usage data or personal information. Bluma stores data related to your menstrual health
dataUse.usage: This data is used solely to provide you with period predictions, cycle insights, and personalized tracking features. We do not share, sell, or transmit your personal health data to any third parties.
dataUse.deletion: If you wish to delete all your app data, you can do so by going to the settings menu and selecting "Delete all data". This will permanently erase all tracking data, health logs, and app settings. You can also delete all data by uninstalling the app.

permissions.title: 2. Permissions
permissions.description: Cicla may request the following permissions:
permissions.biometricSuffix: : To secure your app with fingerprint or face recognition.
permissions.revoke: If you don't want to use any of these permissions, you can revoke them at any time through your device settings.

transparency.title: 3. Transparency
transparency.description: We believe in complete transparency about how your data is handled:
transparency.localStorage: All your data is stored locally and encrypted
transparency.noTransmission: No data is transmitted to external servers
transparency.noAnalytics: We do not use analytics or tracking services
transparency.noAds: No third-party advertising or data collection
transparency.control: You have full control over your data and can delete it at any time through the settings menu.

footer.prefix: If you have any questions about this privacy policy or how we handle your data, please contact my developer at

emptyState.title: No cycle data yet
emptyState.subtitle: Log at least 2 periods to see your personal cycle statistics and history.

cycleDetails.cycleIrregularRange: This cycle length is outside the normal range (21-35 days)
cycleDetails.periodNormalRange: The length of this period was within the normal range (2-7 days)
cycleDetails.periodIrregularRange: This period length is outside the normal range (2-7 days)
cycleDetails.learnAboutLatePeriod: Learn why your period might be late

editPeriod.title: Edit Period
editPeriod.selectDates: Select the dates of your period
editPeriod.instructions: Tap on the calendar to select or deselect dates
editPeriod.confirmDelete: Are you sure you want to delete this period?

view.showOvulation: Show ovulation day and fertile window on the calendar
view.showFuturePeriods: Show future periods prediction on the calendar

accessibility.tapToSelectPeriod: Tap to select as period day

errors.generic: Something went wrong. Please try again.

database.title: Unable to Start App
database.generic: We encountered an issue starting the app. Please try restarting.
database.orphaned: Your encryption key was lost, but your encrypted database still exists. Your previous data cannot be recovered and must be reset to continue using the app.

This will permanently delete all your health data, period tracking history, and settings. This action cannot be undone.

Are you sure you want to continue?

home.noDataPrompt: Log the first day of your last period for next prediction.

cycleInsights.title: Cycle insights
cycleInsights.emptyState: Please log at least one period to view your cycle insights.

phaseDescriptions.menstrual:
The period, or menstruation, is when the lining of the uterus sheds and leaves the body through vaginal bleeding. It typically lasts 3–7 days, but can vary widely. 

During this time, the body prepares for a potential pregnancy by thickening the uterine lining. If fertilization does not occur, hormone levels drop, and menstruation begins.
phaseDescriptions.follicular: The follicular phase is the first part of the menstrual cycle, starting with the first day of your period and ending with ovulation. Energy levels start to rise with increasing estrogen. Good time for starting new projects and physical activity.
phaseDescriptions.ovulatory: Ovulation is the release of an egg from the ovary. This is the peak fertility window, and it typically occurs around day 14 of your cycle.
phaseDescriptions.luteal:
The luteal phase is the second part of the menstrual cycle, lasting from ovulation until the start of your next period, and typically lasts about 12–14 days.

During this time, the body prepares for a potential pregnancy by thickening the uterine lining. If fertilization does not occur, hormone levels drop, and menstruation begins.
phaseDescriptions.extended: Your cycle is running longer than usual (past day 35). This can be normal occasionally, but if it happens often, consider tracking patterns and chatting with a healthcare provider.

pregnancyChanceDescriptions.high: This is your fertile window when conception is most likely to occur. Ovulation typically happens during this time.
pregnancyChanceDescriptions.medium: There is a moderate chance of conception during this time as you approach or move away from your fertile window.
pregnancyChanceDescriptions.low: Conception is less likely during this time. This includes menstrual days and the later luteal phase of your cycle.

symptoms.menstrual: Cramps, fatigue, mood swings, bloating, headaches, and lower back pain. Your energy and mood may be lower than usual.
symptoms.follicular: Rising energy, improved mood, clearer skin, and increased motivation. You may feel more social and confident.
symptoms.ovulatory: Peak energy, heightened sex drive, increased confidence, and possible mild cramping or spotting. You may feel your most attractive.
symptoms.luteal: Bloating, mood swings, food cravings, fatigue, breast tenderness, and irritability. These PMS symptoms typically worsen as your period approaches.

menstrual.title: Menstrual phase
menstrual.description: The first day of your period marks the beginning of your menstrual cycle.

follicular.title: Follicular phase
follicular.description: This phase starts on the first day of your period and lasts until ovulation.

ovulation.title: Ovulation
ovulation.description: This is when an egg is released from your ovary.

luteal.title: Luteal phase
luteal.description: This phase begins after ovulation and ends when your next period starts.

cycleLength.title: Understanding your cycle
cycleLength.definitionText: is counted from the first day of one period to the first day of the next period.

normalRange.title: Normal range
normalRange.acogName: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG)¹
normalRange.acogSuffix: , a normal menstrual cycle typically lasts between
normalRange.variation: Most people have cycles that vary by a few days each month, which is completely normal.

irregular.title: Irregular cycles
irregular.daysRange: shorter than 21 days or longer than 35 days
irregular.descriptionSuffix: and can be caused by a variety of reasons, such as:

causes.weight: Significant weight change or intense exercise

irregular.dataNote: can cause Bluma to indicate an abnormal cycle length. Most often, this is the result of forget to log period. Tracking your cycles for at least 3-6 months will help establish a pattern.

seeDoctor.title: When to see a doctor?
seeDoctor.description: If your cycles are frequently abnormal in length, or/and accompanied by other concerning symptoms, it's best to talk to your health care provider. They can help you figure out the cause and suggest treatment, if necessary.

cycleLength.disclaimer: Bluma is not a diagnostic tool. The information from Bluma does not replace advice from a health care provider. Always seek the advice of your doctor or other qualified health provider with any questions you may have regarding your cycle.

references.title: References
references.acog: 1. Diagnosis of Abnormal Uterine Bleeding in Reproductive-Aged Women. Practice Bulletin. Number 128, July 2012. American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.

periodLength.title: Understanding your period
periodLength.definitionText: is counted from the first until the last day of menstrual bleeding of any volume.

normal.title: Normal period length
normal.acogName: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG)¹
normal.acogSuffix: , a normal period length typically lasts between
normal.variation: Period length can vary from cycle to cycle, which is completely normal.

irregular.title: Irregular periods
irregular.description: Irregular periods (shorter than 2 days or longer than 7 days) might be caused by lifestyle changes, medication, stress, travel, and a few other factors that can affect hormone levels.
irregular.dataNote: could be the reason your period length is labeled prolonged or shortened. You can always correct any event of you cycle retrospectively on the calendar menu.

seeDoctor.title: When to see a doctor?
seeDoctor.description: If your period length is frequently abnormal in length, or/and accompanied by other concerning symptoms, it's best to talk to your health care provider. They can help you figure out the cause and suggest treatment, if necessary.

periodLength.disclaimer: Cicla is not a diagnostic tool. The information from Cicla does not replace advice from a health care provider. Always seek the advice of your doctor or other qualified health provider with any questions you may have regarding your cycle.

references.title: References
references.acog: 1. Your First Period. American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. FAQ for patients.

latePeriod.title: Late period
latePeriod.description: A late period can be caused by stress, changes in weight, or hormonal changes. If your period is more than a week late, consider taking a pregnancy test or consulting your healthcare provider.

whatMeans.title: What means that your period is late?
whatMeans.description: A period is generally considered late when it's more than 5-7 days past your expected date. Cycles can naturally vary by a few days each month, so occasional lateness is normal.

causes.title: Common causes
causes.stressSuffix: High stress affects hormones that regulate your cycle
causes.weightSuffix: Significant gain or loss can delay periods
causes.exerciseSuffix: Intense training can temporarily stop menstruation
causes.illnessSuffix: Being sick can throw off your cycle timing
causes.medicationsSuffix: Birth control, antibiotics, and other drugs
causes.pcosSuffix: Polycystic ovary syndrome causes irregular cycles

seeDoctor.title: When to see a doctor
seeDoctor.description: Consult a healthcare provider if your period is more than 3 months late, if you experience severe pain, or if you've had unprotected sex and could be pregnant. Sudden changes in cycle regularity also warrant a check-up.

whatToDo.title: What you can do
whatToDo.pregnancy: Take a pregnancy test if there's any possibility
whatToDo.stress: Manage stress through meditation, exercise, or therapy
whatToDo.weight: Maintain a healthy weight for your body
whatToDo.track: Track your cycles to identify patterns
whatToDo.patience: Be patient, occasional irregularity is normal

latePeriod.disclaimer: Cicla is not a diagnostic tool. The information from Cicla does not replace advice from a health care provider. Always seek the advice of your doctor or other qualified health provider with any questions you may have regarding your cycle.

references.title: References
references.acog: 1. American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. Abnormal Uterine Bleeding in Reproductive-Aged Women. Practice Bulletin No. 128, July 2012.

prediction.title: How predictions work
prediction.description: Cicla predicts your next period based on your cycle history. The more data you log, the more accurate the predictions become.

nextPeriod.title: Next period prediction
nextPeriod.description: Your next period is predicted by adding your average cycle length to the start date of your most recent period.

cycleLengthCalc.title: Cycle length calculation
cycleLengthCalc.description: Cicla calculates your average cycle length using a weighted average of your last 6 cycles, a commonly used approach in cycle tracking.
cycleLengthCalc.weighting: Recent cycles have more influence on predictions than older ones. For example, most recent cycle: 100%, second most recent: 80%, third most recent: 60%, and so on.

ovulation.title: Ovulation & fertility
ovulation.description: Ovulation is predicted to occur 14 days before your next expected period. Your fertile window includes:
ovulation.fertileWindow: • 5 days before ovulation • Ovulation day • 1 day after ovulation

accuracy.title: Accuracy improves over time
accuracy.description: The more periods you track, the more accurate predictions become. With 3+ cycles, Cicla can provide personalized predictions based on your unique patterns.

privacy.title: Privacy first
privacy.description: All calculations happen locally on your device. Your period data never leaves your phone and is never shared with anyone.

prediction.disclaimerSuffix: : These are predictions based on your historical data. Every body is different, and cycles can vary naturally.

welcome.title: Your period, your data
welcome.subtitle: Track your cycle without compromising your privacy.
welcome.badgeNoTracking: No ads and no external tracking

periodLength.title: How long does your period usually last?
periodLength.checkboxText: Don't know - let the app learn
periodLength.checkboxSubtext: The app will use 5 days as a default, and then adjust as you log cycles.

cycleLength.title: How many days does your cycle last on average?
cycleLength.subtitle: This is the number of days from the start of one period to the start of the next.
cycleLength.checkboxText: Don't know - let the app learn
cycleLength.checkboxSubtext: The app will use 28 days as a default, and then adjust as you log cycles.

lastPeriod.title: When was the start of your last period?
lastPeriod.subtitle: This will help us to predict your next period.
lastPeriod.checkboxSubtext: It's okay, you can do it later inside the app.

success.title: You're all set!
success.subtitle: Predictions become more accurate after logging 3-6 cycles. Keep tracking regularly for the best results.

tracking.title: Track your health
tracking.notesPlaceholder: Add notes, any extra symptoms, etc.
tracking.notesEditorPlaceholder: Add notes, any extra symptoms, or how you've been feeling...

periodStarting.title: Your period might start today
periodStarting.body: Your period might start today. Log it in the app!

periodLate.title: Your period is late
periodLate.body: Your period was expected yesterday. Did you forget to log your period?
